Literature Review: Fungi, representing a significant portion of eukaryotic diversity, play crucial roles in ecosystems worldwide, yet their comprehensive understanding remains a challenge. The estimation of fungal species diversity has been a subject of extensive debate, with recent studies suggesting a revised estimate of 2–3 million species, pinpointing a 'best estimate' at 2.5 million (Hawksworth & Lücking, 2017). This vast diversity, largely unexplored, underscores the urgent need for innovative approaches to catalog and understand fungal life. The proposal to recognize species known only from DNA data and the call for large-scale sampling campaigns are pivotal steps towards unveiling the hidden fungal diversity (Tedersoo et al., 2014). The integration of metabarcoding techniques has revolutionized fungal biodiversity research, enabling the identification of species from environmental samples without the need for cultivation (Bálint et al., 2015). This approach has been instrumental in highlighting the diversity and distribution patterns of fungi, particularly in tropical and temperate ecoregions, which are identified as hotspots of fungal richness (Arnold & Lutzoni, 2007). The fungus:plant ratio, a critical metric in understanding fungal diversity, varies significantly across different ecosystems, reflecting the complex interactions between fungi and their plant hosts (Peay et al., 2016). Despite their ecological importance, fungi have been largely neglected in conservation efforts. The call for further Red List assessments and the development of enhanced management guidelines are essential steps towards the conservation of fungal diversity (Dahlberg & Mueller, 2011). In situ and ex situ conservation strategies, tailored to the unique biology of fungi, are crucial for preserving their diversity and ecological functions (Senn-Irlet et al., 2007). The role of fungi in ecosystems, from nutrient cycling to symbiotic relationships, underscores their inseparable connection to all life forms on Earth (van der Heijden et al., 2015). As we push the frontiers of biodiversity research, fungi emerge as a fascinating and critical area of study, promising to unravel new insights into the complexity of life on our planet (Blackwell, 2011).
